choices.text: Bacterial vaginosis
Physiological discharge
Trichomonas vaginitis
Vulvovaginal candidiasis

questions.text: A 20-year-old unmarried girl presents to OPD with complaint of discharge per vagina. The discharge is white sticky discharge which is more prominent on few days after menses. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Physiological discharge

 

  • Normal vaginal secretions are floccular in consistency, white or transparent in color and may stain the undergarments
  • Physiological discharge appears few days after menstruation, increases in amount and after ovulation, becomes thicker.

 

Let's look at each option:

 

Option A. Bacterial Vaginosis: Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance in the vaginal microbiota. It's not typically associated with inflammation. The discharge in BV is usually grey or white, thin, and has a distinctive "fishy" Odor, especially after sexual intercourse. Unlike the scenario described, it doesn't tend to be sticky or cyclically related to menstruation.

 

Option B. Physiological Discharge: This is the correct answer for the case described. Physiological vaginal discharge is normal and varies throughout the menstrual cycle. It is usually clear or white, floccular (flaky), and can be sticky. The amount and consistency change with the menstrual cycle, often becoming more noticeable after menstruation and around ovulation when it becomes thicker.

 

Option C. Trichomonas Vaginitis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It typically presents with a frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a strong odor. There may also be itching, discomfort, and redness around the vagina, which are not described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Vulvovaginal Candidiasis:  Commonly known as a yeast infection, it's caused by the overgrowth of Candida, a type of fungus. The discharge in candidiasis is typically thick, white, and curd-like, often described as resembling cottage cheese. It's usually accompanied by itching, redness, and irritation, which are not mentioned in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: JB Sharma Textbook of Gynecology 4th edition

choices.text: Gram positive cocci
Gram positive bacilli
Gram negative cocci
Gram negative bacilli

questions.text: A gram stain from vaginal secretions will show predominantly:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gram positive bacilli

 

  • Gram stain revels gram positive bacilli (lactobacilli)

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Gram Positive Cocci: Gram-positive cocci, include bacteria such as Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species. While these bacteria can be present in the vaginal flora, they are not the predominant in a healthy vagina.

 

Option B. Gram Positive Bacilli : Gram-positive bacilli include species like Lactobacillus. In a healthy vaginal environment, Lactobacillus species are predominant, maintaining a low pH environment that is hostile to many pathogenic bacteria.

 

Option C. Gram Negative Cocci: This group includes Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which causes gonorrhea. Gram-negative cocci are not typically the predominant bacteria in normal vaginal secretions. Their presence in significant numbers can indicate infection.

 

Option D. Gram Negative Bacilli:  These are rod-shaped bacteria  such as Escherichia coli. While gram-negative bacilli can be part of the vaginal flora, they are not usually predominant in healthy individuals.

 

Educational Objective: The vaginal environment is predominantly inhabited by Lactobacillus species (Gram-positive bacilli), which play a crucial role in maintaining vaginal health by producing lactic acid, thereby keeping the pH low and preventing colonization by pathogenic organisms

 

Ref: Berek & Novak 16 ed, page 883

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to OPD with discharge per vagina. On examination, there is grayish discharge with fishy odor. Vaginal pH is 5.5.   Which of the following kit will you prescribe her:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Green kit

 

  • This patient has vaginal discharge which points towards bacterial vaginosis
  • Green kit is used for treatment of vaginal discharge and includes Secnidazole and fluconazole
  • AMSEL’S criteria is used for diagnosing BV. This includes 3 out of 4 of:

 

  1. Greyish white discharge
  2. Vaginal pH> 4.7 (alkaline)
  3.  Drop of discharge mixed with 10% KOH = Fishy odour (due to release of amines, acridine, and putredine) = Whiff test
  4.  Smear prepared with normal saline: Clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells covered with coccobacilli and the cells appear as stippled or granular).

 

  • In syndromic approach
    • Kit 1: gray: urethral discharge (men), cervical discharge (women)
    • Kit 2: green: vaginal discharge
    • Kit 6: yellow kit: PID/ lower abdominal pain syndrome
    • Kit 3: white / 4 blue: non herpetic ulcers
    • Kit 5: red: herpetic ulcer
    • Kit 7: black: inguinal bubo

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Berek & Novak, 16 ed, page number 884

choices.text: Associated with strawberry cervix
Candida albicans is the likely organism
Metronidazole will be effective in treatment
Vaginal pH is <4.5

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to STI clinic with complaint of discharge. The wet mount of the patient is given below. Which of the following is TRUE:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metronidazole will be effective in treatment

 

  • The picture given is of clue cells which is seen in bacterial vaginosis ( Clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells covered with coccobadilli and the cells appear as stippled or granular).
  • Amsel criteria is used to diagnose Bacterial vaginosis
  • Treatment includes:
    • Metronidazole oral tablets/gel
    • Clindamycin: oral/ cream/vaginal tablet
  • Kit2 (green kit) is given for BV and other vaginal discharge and it contains:
    • Secnidazole 2g (for bacterial vaginosis and trichomonas vaginalis)
    • Fluconazole 150mg (for candidiasis)

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Associated with Strawberry Cervix: False. A cervix that appears red with small, pinpoint haemorrhages. It is commonly associated with trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis typically shows motile trichomonads on wet mount whereas this image shows clue cells.

 

Option B. Candida albicans is the Likely Organism: False. Candida albicans, a yeast, causes vaginal candidiasis. It is characterized by thick, white discharge and might show budding yeasts or hyphae on a wet mount.

 

Option C. Metronidazole will be Effective in Treatment: Metronidazole is an antibiotic effective against certain anaerobic bacteria and protozoa. It is the treatment of choice for bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis. The statement is true since the wet mount shows clue cells seen in bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Vaginal pH is <4.5: False. A vaginal pH of less than 4.5 is typical of a healthy vagina and is common in yeast infections. A higher pH (above 4.5) is more consistent with bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis. If metronidazole is effective, it suggests a diagnosis other than a yeast infection, likely corresponding to a higher vaginal pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref:  Berek & novak, 16 ed, page number 884

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with foul smelling discharge. Speculum examination shows. Which kit will you give to the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kit 2

 

  • The discharge is homogenous white milky discharge which is coating vaginal walls, suggesting bacterial vaginosis.
  • Kit 2 or green kit is for vaginal discharge syndrome
  • In syndromic approach
    • Kit 1: gray: urethral discharge (men), cervical discharge (women)
    • Kit 2: green: vaginal discharge
    • Kit 6: yellow kit: PID/ lower abdominal pain syndrome
    • Kit 3: white / 4 blue: non herpetic ulcers
    • Kit 5: red: herpetic ulcer
    • Kit 7: black: inguinal bubo

 

Educational Objective: Foul-smelling discharge is often indicative of a bacterial infection, such as bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis, which requires specific antibiotic treatment. Homogenous white milky discharge which is coating vaginal walls, suggests bacterial vaginosis. Kit 2 or green kit is for vaginal discharge syndrome

 

Reference: National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) colour-coded kits for syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs)

choices.text: Associated with strawberry cervix
Kit 1 will be useful
Will be associated with curdy white discharge
Fluconazole is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaint of discharge per vagina associated with intense itching. Wet mount of vaginal secretions is shown below. Which of the following is TRUE:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Associated with strawberry cervix

 

  • Flagellated motile trichomonads are shown in the picture: This patient has trichomonas vaginitis
  • Trichomonas vaginitis
    • Caused by flagellated parasite, Trichomonas vaginalis
    • Associated with profuse frothy, greenish, malodorous discharge
    • Associated with intense vulvar pruritis
    • Patchy vaginal erythema or colpitis macularis (strawberry cervix) may be present
    • Pregnant women with trichomonas are at increased risk of PROM and preterm labor
    • Treatment is with metronidazole and tinidazole
    • Kit 2 is used (green kit)

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Associated with Strawberry Cervix: A "strawberry cervix" is characterized by a red, inflamed appearance with small, pinpoint haemorrhage. It is a classic sign of trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. The wet mount showed motile trichomonads, supporting the diagnosis of trichomoniasis.

 

Option B. Kit 1 will be Useful: False. Kit 2 is generally used for treating specific types of vaginal infections.

 

Option C. Will be Associated with Curdy White Discharge: A curdy white discharge is typically associated with Candida albicans infection .It's thick, white, and often resembles cottage cheese. This type of discharge is not characteristic of trichomoniasis, which usually presents with a frothy, greenish-yellow, malodorous discharge.

 

Option D. Fluconazole is the Treatment of Choice: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat yeast infections caused by Candida.If trichomoniasis is the diagnosed condition, fluconazole would not be the appropriate treatment, as it is ineffective against the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Berek & novak 16ed, page 885

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1c    2a     3d      4b

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) colour-coded kits for syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs)

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD with greenish frothy discharge. You prescribe her kit 2 for trichomonas vaginitis. Which drug in the kit is likely to act on this flagellate:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secnidazole

 

  • Kit 1 contains: cefixime 400mg and azithromycin 1 g: and these are used for cervical discharge syndrome
  • Kit 2 contains: fluconazole 150 mg and Secnidazole 2g
  • Fluconazole acts on candida for vulvovaginal candidiasis
  • And secnidazole acts for Bacterial Vaginosis and Trichomonas Vaginitis

 

Let's explore each option:

 

Option A. Cefixime: Cefixime is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. It's effective against a range of bacterial infections. It's not effective against trichomonas vaginitis, as Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite, not a bacterium.

 

Option B. Azithromycin: Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic. It's used to treat various bacterial infections, including some sexually transmitted infections. Similar to cefixime, azithromycin is ineffective against protozoan infections .

 

Option C. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used primarily to treat yeast infections. It's not effective against Trichomonas vaginalis, as it's designed to target fungal cells, not protozoan parasites.

 

Option D. Secnidazole: Secnidazole is a nitroimidazole antibiotic that is effective against protozoan infections, including Trichomonas vaginalis. This is the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Reference: National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) colour-coded kits for syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs)

choices.text: Wet mount will show clue cells
Wet mount will show flagellated organism
Single dose fluconazole is sufficient for treatment
Single dose azithromycin is sufficient for treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic woman presents to OPD with vaginal discharge. Which of the following is true for this:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Single dose fluconazole is sufficient for treatment

 

  • This is candidiasis
  • Clue cells seen in bacterial vaginosis
  • Flagellated organism in trichomonas
  • Fluconazole is treatment for candidiasis
  • Azithromycin is used in cervical discharge syndrome

 

Now, let’s  explore each option and their relevance to the provided scenario:

 

Option A. Wet Mount will Show Clue Cells: Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria, typically seen in bacterial vaginosis. While diabetes can increase the risk of various infections, the presence of clue cells is not specifically linked to diabetes.

 

Option B. Wet Mount will Show Flagellated Organism: Flagellated organisms, such as Trichomonas vaginalis, can cause trichomoniasis, which is characterized by a frothy, greenish discharge. If trichomoniasis was the cause, metronidazole or tinidazole would be the treatment of choice.

 

Option C. Single Dose Fluconazole is Sufficient for Treatment: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat yeast infections, such as those caused by Candida albicans. The patient's symptoms are likely due to a yeast infection, which is not uncommon in diabetic patients due to altered glucose metabolism that can affect the vaginal flora.

 

Option D. Single Dose Azithromycin is Sufficient for Treatment: Azithromycin is an antibiotic used for bacterial infections, including some sexually transmitted infections not for candida.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Berek & Novak 16 ed page 886

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaint of itching in vagina, discharge from vagina and dyspareunia. Best treatment option would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal estrogen

 

  • This is a postmenopausal woman with atrophic vaginitis. Treated with vaginal estrogen and steroids.

 

Let's examine each treatment option:

 

Option A. Vaginal Metronidazole: While it's effective against bacterial vaginosis, the symptoms described are more indicative of atrophic vaginitis due to estrogen deficiency, which is not treated with metronidazole.

 

Option B. Vaginal Clindamycin: Similar to metronidazole, clindamycin is not the appropriate treatment if the underlying cause is atrophic vaginitis related to menopausal changes.

 

Option C. Vaginal Clotrimazole: Although yeast infections can cause itching and discharge, the patient's age and symptoms suggest a more likely diagnosis of atrophic vaginitis due to decreased estrogen levels.

 

Option D. Vaginal Estrogen: Vaginal estrogen therapy is used to treat genitourinary symptoms of menopause, such as vaginal dryness, itching, and dyspareunia. The patient's age and symptoms are consistent with atrophic vaginitis, a condition commonly seen in postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women, symptoms like vaginal itching, discharge, and dyspareunia are often due to decreased estrogen levels, leading to atrophic vaginitis. Vaginal estrogen therapy is an effective treatment for atrophic vaginitis, addressing the underlying hormonal deficiency.

 

Ref: Berek & Novak, 16 ed Page 891

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with multiple sexual partners comes with complaint of vaginal discharge. On examination, cervix is eroded with mucopurulent discharge. Which of the following kits will you give her:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kit 1

 

  • The patient has multiple sexual partners, cervical erosion and mucopurulent discharge: The patient has cervicitis.
  • It’s important to note that for both vaginitis and cervicitis, the patient will have complaints of vaginal discharge. Both types of discharge will be expelled through vagina so, the patient will say vaginal discharge. But the examination will confirm vaginitis from cervicitis

 

  • In syndromic approach
    • kit 1: gray: urethral discharge (men), cervical discharge (women)
    • Kit 2: green: vaginal discharge
    • Kit 6: yellow kit: PID/ lower abdominal pain syndrome
    • Kit 3: white / 4 blue: non herpetic ulcers
    • Kit 5: red: herpetic ulcer
    • Kit 7: black: inguinal bubo

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In syndromic approach
    • Kit 1: gray: urethral discharge (men), cervical discharge (women)
    • Kit 2: green: vaginal discharge
    • Kit 6: yellow kit: PID/ lower abdominal pain syndrome
    • Kit 3: white / 4 blue: non herpetic ulcers
    • Kit 5: red: herpetic ulcer
    • Kit 7: black: inguinal bubo

 

Ref: Berek & Novak 16 ed, page 891

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of cervicitis:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

  • Most common cause of cervicitis are Neisseria gonorrhoeae, & Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Treatment of Neisseria
    • Ceftriaxone+ azithromycin
    • Cefixime + azithromycin
  • Treatment of Chlamydia
    • Azithromycin
    • Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7 days

 

Let's explore each option presented in the question:

 

Option A. Neisseria gonorrhoeae:  This is the correct answer. Gonorrhoea is a leading cause of cervicitis. The infection can cause symptoms like vaginal discharge, pain during urination, and intermenstrual bleeding.

 

Option B. Trichomonas vaginalis: While Trichomonas can cause cervicitis, it is less common than Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The infection often presents with a frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge and itching.

 

Option C. Candida albicans: Candida is not a common cause of cervicitis. It usually results in vaginal candidiasis, presenting with symptoms like itching, redness, and a thick, white discharge.

 

Option D. Gardnerella vaginalis: Although Gardnerella can be part of the complex flora involved in BV, it's not typically a primary cause of cervicitis. BV is more characterized by symptoms like a fishy-smelling vaginal discharge and vaginal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Most common cause of cervicitis are Neisseria gonorrhoeae, & Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Treatment of Neisseria
    • Ceftriaxone+ azithromycin
    • Cefixime + azithromycin
  • Treatment of Chlamydia
    • Azithromycin
    • Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7 days

 

Ref: Berek & Novak 16 ed, 891
